title: reference request - mean curvature for codimension $>1$?
body: The mean curvature of a hypersurface in a Riemannian manifold is defined to be the trace of the second fundamental form. I was curious, does the notion of mean curvature generalise to higher codimension objects, if so how is this defined? If not, how come this notion does not make much sense in higher codimensions? Any reference or explanation is appreciated, thank you. reference-request dg.differential-geometry riemannian-geometry curvature Share Cite Improve this question Follow asked Jul 16, 2020 at 6:27 Johnny T. 3,773 1 1 gold badge 17 17 silver badges 32 32 bronze badges $\endgroup$ 3 5 $\begingroup$ It is defined as the trace of the second fundamental form, but the second fundamental form is normal bundle valued. And usually you scale by the inverse of the dimension of the submanifold. $\endgroup$ Sebastian –  Sebastian 2020-07-16 06:52:37 +00:00 Commented Jul 16, 2020 at 6:52 $\begingroup$ Thank you. do you happen to have reference by any chance? $\endgroup$ Johnny T. –  Johnny T. 2020-07-16 07:15:49 +00:00 Commented Jul 16, 2020 at 7:15 3 $\begingroup$ Chapter 5.C in the Riemannian geometry book of Gallot-Hulin-Lafontaine. $\endgroup$ Sebastian –  Sebastian 2020-07-16 08:46:00 +00:00 Commented Jul 16, 2020 at 8:46 Add a comment  |  0 Sorted by: Reset to default Highest score (default) Date modified (newest first) Date created (oldest first) You must log in to answer this question.
